Extra bolts are joined by a small piece at the base for added stability when printing.

I made this to help prevent the filament from unspooling and winding around the spool holder between my Replicator and the spool by holding the filament away from the back of the case. It seems to work quite well for me. I also found that when I tried to put it on the tubing holder, that I needed to slot all the way around the the holder and not just the slots I added. A little filing or cutting works great. It's was designed as a tight fit.

I printed it at 100% fill (you want it strong because the clips are steel) with raft and supports.
The supports were easily cut off and the center hole cleaned out pretty well using a flat tip screwdriver. A drill would work well too, just so the Replicators tubing fits in. I designed this in 123d Design and added the file so anyone can modify it as needed.

title: K8200/3DRAG Z axis stepper mount (rework of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:232446)

description.text: This is the same as http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:232446, but with a separate microswitch bracket to glue on (makes it easier to print) and with the mounting portion redesigned to fit the extrusion profile for greater rigidity and better alignment

When I printed the original part I damaged the Z endstop microswitch mount while trying to remove the support material. I decided to file it off and print a separate microswitch bracket to glue on. This worked fine, but the original part has little support behind the mounting screws, and this caused it to bendif the screws are tightened. I reworked the area behind the mounting holes, so that the position of the motor shaft is more reliably close to the original printer mount. I also had to print a small spacer for the z axis microswitch because witht he plate vertical wall straight it doesn't match too well with the endstop screw. Probably it would be better to adjust the microswitch bracket to be a little offset from the current position

description.text: please see the pic.

Designed with the "Defence of the Ancients 2" logo this is a keycap for MX Cherry keyboards, the LED on the MX Cherry switch will light up through the model creating a glowing effect, especially with red/orange plastic. Dota 2 is played in discrete matches involving two five-player teams, each of which occupies a stronghold at a corner of the map. Each stronghold contains a building called the "Ancient", which the opposite team must destroy to win the match.
​
I once found a store that sold dota 2 keycaps but they were out of stock and the store would'nt order in more.. So when I got a 3d printer ​I knew exactley what I wanted to make. So I took an allready existing keycap and slapped the DotA 2 logo on there and printed it, I had many mis-prints but I was new to printing at the time and eventually I got the perfect print. I decided to go with red plastic because the DotA 2 logo is red but I had no idea how awesome it would turn out, when I attached the keycap to my keyboard and powered on the computer the keycap lit up like if it was made of molten iron or lava.
Credits to the Valve Corporation for designing the logo

description.header: Check out my other Dota2 things and follow if you want to get notifications when I make something!

description.text:
Print without supports and at low speed. If it doesnt fit on your keyboard you can try to make the "+" hole bigger with a knife or print it again at 101% size. Here are my Slic3r settings I used when I printed mine:
-Layers:
Layer height: 0.1 mm (0.2 mm works fine too)
Solid layers: 3
Perimeters: 2
Extra perimeters if needed: Yes
Avoid crossing perimeters: Yes
Detect thin walls: Yes
Detect bridging perimeters: Yes -Speed:
perimeters: 15 mm / sec
small perimeters: 5mm / sec
The rest of the settings were standard, enjoy your new keycap!

title: K8200/3Drag Z axis bearing support (rework of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:175137)

description.text:
I reworked the geometry to eliminate non manifold faces, to clean up the geometry and to align the centre of rotation better to the original kit piece. I have also recessed the screw in order to be able reuse screw and washer from the Velleman kit, but I don't know if the 3Drag uses the same hardware. The distance of the shaft from the frame matches http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:232446
(and my own rework http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:443084).
The second picture shows the same object with a 2nd bearing mounted underneath it to ensure the axis cannot be simply lifted off the bearing holder, for example when the printer is used as a small CNC router. A word of warning. After several hours of use my print finally delaminated. I temporarily fixed it by gluing it back together and tying a zip tie vertically around it. I will probably beef this up and maybe work out a way for the zip tie to be a permanent feature.

comments.text: you somehow managed to make the bearing holder .2mm too small, tried to make it and failed multiple times. my printer is perfectly calibrated. Therefore i inspected the model and noticed that the hole actually is smaller. just a bit, but it renders the piece useless.
comments.author: 3dNoScope

comments.text: I didn't change the size from the original, and it's a snug press fit on my PLA prints. In any case the bearing should not be loose in the holder. You could try just force-fitting it with a vice, the material should be flexible enough to accommodate for it. As a comparison, I did make the holes in my pulleys for http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:465631 slightly narrower to ensure they could be friction fit on 608 bearings without having to be glued, and yet they still can be fitted.
comments.author: 3dNoScope

This is rail car number two in what (I hope) will be a series of ten, one published every two weeks until Christmas. This O gauge car (wheels, axle, coupler and bed are all 3D printed plastic) is part of an active train. It requires a hexbug (available on amazon.com) to run around in the car's bed.
http://youtu.be/3oII3hsYjag

Print the parts using low resolution and supports.
Print 4 wheel sets, 2 carriers, 1 bed and 2 bed caps and two bed ends.
Insert the wheels into the carriers, then set the bed on the posts. Glue the bed caps to the top of the posts. Set the bed ends inside the car, then add a hexbug (available at amazon.com).

remixed_from.author: 3dCouverte
remixed_from.title: K8200 Z axis nut-holder anti wobbling and backlash

title: K8200/3Drag Z-axis wobble and backlash reducer

description.text: This is my attempt at reducing Z-Wobble on the K8200. There is more detail about the concept and additional hardware needed in the instructions.

Additional hardware needed to build this:
2 x 30mm M10 steel washers
2 x M8 steel nuts
1 x M3 bolt, nut and washer
optional:
2 x M8 plastic washers
2 x M8 steel washers
The stepper mount used in the picture is http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:443084, and it can't really hold the weight of the Z axis securely, so the threaded rod is suspended by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:443103. When assembling it is better to tighten the threaded rod/stepper adapter last, so that the weight is entirely supported by the upper bearing.
This thing is partly inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:304424, but the anti-backlash spring on that part is not really effective since it only pushes one nut against the other while leaving the frame unaffected. I had two 30mm wide M10 washers handy, and I thought this would give me a more regular surface for the driving nuts to slide on than a printed PLA surface. In my build I am using nylon M8 washers backed by steel M8 washers to ensure the thing is sturdy, but I bet that a printed M8 PLA washer will work just as well to avoid having a metal/metal sliding surface interface. My build is definitely overkill, but I had all the bits, so why not use them? I didn't have a suitable spring, and since winter is a few months off I don't have a discarded umbrella to cannibalize.To overcome that I designed a PLA spring that can be printed in several sections to be stacked. For the original dimensions you will need two prints of part a and one print of part b (part b has a small step that holds the upper washer frame in place, which in turn keeps the spring centred) The nut holder will also have to be printed twice. Several parts have to be flipped upside/down in order to print easily without support, the STL files show them in their assembly position. the mounting block, spring parts, upper washer frame and nut holder all print better upside-down. When assembling it is a bit difficult to get the spring to push on the upper washer with the right strength, It may be necessary to rotate the nut in the nut holder by a fraction of a turn, but in order to do that it has to be removed from the thread, so it is probably a good idea to temporarily mark one spot on the nut with a permanent marker.

title: Solidoodle 2 (2nd Gen) Dremel Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a mount interface for the Solidoodle 2 (2nd Gen) and a Dremel rotary tool, which will turn your Solidoodle into a CNC mill.
Originally based on the X-dremel mount by lasernipples. I didn't want to replace the whole carriage, so I extracted the threads and bolt holes from this model and created my own.
Detailed instructions on Instructables.

Brief overview here:
Remove the extruder (two bolts underneath)
Place this directly on top of the x-axis carriage
Bolt it down with the extruder bolts
Secure your extruder
Thread in your Dremel tool
CAM pathing, alignment, and such detailed in this Instructable

author: eguevara78

title: Printrbot Simple 1405 Y-Axis GT2 Belt Tensioner Replacement Part

description.header: Please try the updated version of this thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:455019
description.text:
The Y-Axis Tensioner broke on my Printrbot Simple 1405, so I created this part to replace it.
I have printed this and managed to break this part as well after two prints. My belt could have been tensioned too tight, but I'm going to work on an alternate tensioner design, so keep checking my designs.

I printed this on a Printrbot Simple Metal to replace the broken wooden piece on my Printrbot Simple 1405 (Wooden).
I have printed one item on the 1405 with this part in place and it worked fine.
It may be good to print a spare even if you do not need it if you only have access to a single printer.
Layer height was around 0.2mm. I'm not sure exactly what infill settings should be used, I think my slicing program automatically infills the entire piece since it is small.
It should take between ten to twenty minutes to print.
The part is almost exactly like the original, except the belt will fit more snugly and the screw holes require actual pressure to get the screws to thread into them.
When replacing the part, I still used the M3 nuts for strength. The screws will hold in the plastic piece, which helps while installing it.

This is my first design in thingivers.
This design started my wish which quite stable printer on however height and width extended. My own printer used normal ball bushing but it's limit of vibration and quality was not satisfied me.
I used printer's structure of the 20X20 aluminium profile. One day I made idea which make own ball bushing insert 7mm bearing ball as a moving part ball bushing over the profile structure.
It's very stable and good movement on printing time so I can make very nice and stable printing.
This module was first time tested before printer parts simply made.
My new machine using this module named "WAVIEW" will reveal next week.
Also you can visit and find out our new product here.

description.text:
This is a holder designed to fit onto the side of my replicator to allow me to use the large diameter spools that some filament comes on.
It has a slight angle to encourage the spool to slide towards the frame rather than off it, and a small diameter (34mm) to fit most spool holes.
Not given them much of a test yet, but they look quite funky!

It's a bit over-engineered and took a couple of hours to print both left and right versions on my replicator, but the filament spools are quite heavy.  I used a 10% fill and it seems very solid - you could probably get away with less.
It screws to the side of the Replicator using the middle case screw - or rather it doesn't because it's a bit too thick, so I had to use a slightly longer M3 (only a couple of mills longer).

comments.text: If you read my post it didn't have to do with the type of plastic it is made of. All 3d prints (including sintering) have very small pores that bacteria can easily inhabit. They will breed and make things unsafe contaminating them. This is why you are not supposed to make any cups or foodware no matter what plastic(yes even food safe plastic). You have to coat the plastic in a glaze coating. So I was asking if this was safe for tat reason. I don't know if the acids in a lemon may neutralize any threat or if the author never heard of this problem before.
comments.author: YLAG

comments.text: Would an acetone smoothing step followed by some outgassing perhaps fix the pore issue? Seems like it would, and it would make the result quite pretty. Acetone evaporates quickly, leaving just the smooth, shiny plastic.
comments.author: Tyscof

comments.text: Yea I think I have read somewhere that they may help, The only problem that I would foresee is not actually getting all of the surface smooth or if the acetone bath just makes it seem smooth but If you put it under a microscope you would still find a pores structure. I am not sure if this is the case just something to keep in mind, best bet would just be to glaze anything food wise like what they do with ceramics.
comments.author: darco

comments.text: Even with an acetone bath (which only works on ABS, not PLA), you still have issues of lead poising and other contaminants coming from the printhead.  Printheads are not sterile and you have in your prints everything from you previous prints (so if you used ABS, ever, it will be in the prints).  Home prints really are not meant for food safe objects.  People look to plastic way to much as being safe/inert material, when it really isn't.
comments.author: Tyscof

comments.text: What makes you think that ABS is not safe and PLA is ?
comments.author: YLAG

comments.text:
Actually, none of the plastics used in 3D-printing can be food-safe as long as the FDM process IS NOT a food-safe process. Meaning that even food-safe filament (which have received an FDA certification), are no more food-safe, once printed !
Since commercially avaible 3D-printers are relatively new, we don't have enough perspective to assess those kind of contaminations.

description.text:
rev 4: minor bug fixes.
rev 3: added insets for the Chicago screws at the wrist.
rev 2: minor tweaks, cleaned up code. I designed this gauntlet to go with the Cyborg Beast palm. The main thing is to get the outside wrist width to fit in the palm. Outside wrist width = prmR1 * 2.0 + prmThickness + prmPivotExtra
I liked the idea of having the Velcro slots oriented out to help eliminate a lot of support material. This is the 4th revision and has proved to be strong, and not requiring knots is nice. Each finger can be finely adjusted and readjusted independently. Parameters:
  • Chicago screw radius, etc
  • overall wall thickness
  • length
  • front radius
  • back radius
  • several for wrist pivot positioning
  • front/back brace widths (the middle brace is an average)
    Inspired by http://enablingthefuture.org
    The sample gtlt_R26_R32_L130.stl has a front radius of 26,
    back radius of 32 and a Length of 130.
    HINT: This model is round, so in your 3D printer software scale the
    Z axis to 90% to 'squish' it to a more natural shape. (this will be fixed shortly)
    Q: Why are the 5 Chicago screw holes not centered on the back? A: This is designed for a left hand. The holes are placed (and offset to the left) so that the strings can be easily readjusted while being worn.

This is a small command line tool to analyse gcodes. It calculates various print details like
-print time
-used filament
-yx move distance
-print object dimension
-average print speeds
-number of layers
-layer details
-speed distribution
-weight and price of the printed object
...
UPDATE 0.98 Now with edit mode (experimental) **
Change the print speed by percent
Change the extrusion rate by percent
Change the Layerheight by percent (+increase extrusion)
Modify extruder temperatur (only update existing gcodes)
Modify bed temperatur (only update existing gcodes)
Add Offset to Z position (requires layer option 'all'
Add Offset to X position (requires layer option 'all'
Add Offset to Y position (requires layer option 'all'
Modify Fan options 0=off, 255=full (only update existing gcodes)
Delete the specified layers I used it to optimize my slicer settings and print times for my reprap printer.
Tested mostly with slic3r generated gcodes.

Source Code now available at Github: https://github.com/dietzm/GCodeInfo

Added guessed info about print material and diameter
Added info about mass and weight (based on guessed material info)
Added info about price (based on guessed material info + default price per kg=30Ã¢âÂ¬)
Ability to specify environment variables to overwrite diameter and price per kg (FILAMENT_DIAMETER, FILAMENT_PRICE_KG)
(Guessing of PLA or ABS is based on temperature, Diameter guessing based slicer comments or rough guess assuming WOT=~2) .
Fixed some issues with Skeinforge comments and average calulations. *UPDATE V0.94 Version**
Added support for Java 1.6 (MacOS) *UPDATE V0.93 Version**
Fixed issues with Z-Lift and negative coordinates.
Added "position on print bed" to model details.
Show gcode load time and analyse time.
Added undodumented option "g" for debugging (print gcode details) Start the java program by calling on the command line (Java 1.7.x required)
java -jar GCodeInfo.jar [mplnscg] gcode_file GcodeUtil 0.91
Usage: GcodeUtil [mode m|p|n] gcodefile [
Modes:
m = Show Model Info
l = Show Layer Summary
p = Show Printed Layer Detail Info
n = Show Non-Printed Layer Detail Info
s = Show Printing Speed Details Info
c = Show embedded comments (e.g. from slicer)
Edit Mode Usage: GcodeUtil [editmode e] [option] [layers] gcodefile
e speed=-10 = Reduce Speed by 10 percent
e extr=10 = Increase extrusion rate by 10 percent
e layerh=10 = Increase Layerheight by 10 percent (+increase extrusion)
e exttemp=170.3 = Set extruder temperatur to 170.3 (only update existing gcodes)
e bedtemp=50.3 = Set bed temperatur to 50.3 (only update existing gcodes)
e zoffset=0.1 = Add Offset to Z position (requires layer option 'all'
e xoffset=0.1 = Add Offset to X position (requires layer option 'all'
e yoffset=0.1 = Add Offset to Y position (requires layer option 'all'
e fan=255 = Set Fan 0=off, 255=full (only update existing gcodes)
e delete = Delete the specified layers
[layers] = comma separated list of layers or 'all' for all Example:
Show Model Info and Printed Layers
GcodeUtil mp /tmp/object.gcode
Show All Info
GcodeUtil mlpnsc /tmp/object.gcode
Edit Model, increase 1-3 layer speed by 25%
GcodeUtil e speed=25 1,2,3 /tmp/object.gcode

description.text:
A very simple graduation cap. I added a hole on the top in the center for people to add tassels. I rounded the corner because after 4 years of grueling hard work, nobody should lose an eye, plastic caps are HARD. I based the dimensions off of http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_head#mediaviewer/File:HeadAnthropometry.JPG
looking at the 50th percentile. THIS DESIGN HAS NOT BEEN TESTED AND IS NOT RECOMMENDED TO BE TOSSED. USE WITH CAUTION!

This is a simplified version of Prusajr's PLA bushings. The geometry is nearly identical, but a parameter has been added to make the walls thicker/thinner, so that it can be printed with a different nozzle size without needing infill. The nominal contact area with the bar is also reduced slightly my making the tips that make contact flat instead of rounded.
It simplified because it is built in 2D and extruded, and uses less than half as many lines of code.

title: Lens Hood for Canon Rebel T3i - 58mm

description.text:
NOTE: This thing is based off of thing 15191 by whisperoftheshot. You might need that version depending on how thin the lip has to be that slides under the groove to lock the hood in place.
This is a 58mm Canon Lens Hood. The difference between this one and the one published by whisperoftheshot is that I modified the part that clips to the lens to be much thinner that the one it is based off of.
I'm not sure if or when Canon changed the groove on their lenses but the original would fit none of mine. The slide lock on the original is maybe 3 to 4 mm. Whereas on my camera lenses from Canon, it's a 1mm slide.
I recommend you just print out the first few mm of layers, and then cancel the print, and see if it will attache to your camera. That way you don't waste time printing the whole thing.

title: Type A Machines 2014  Improved Spool holder with bearings and G2 extruder lower guide

description.text:
This is an improved spool holder for 2014 Series 1 Type A machines printer. It features two skate bearings and requires an M8x100 bolt with two M8 nuts
Update:
After running this bracket for a 24 hour solid print I noticed that the weight of the reel causes it to sag and as a result the reel always ends up at the far end of the spindle. The end ridge kept it on fine, but in the later stages of a 24 hour print I was paranoid it might fall off so kept an eye on it (it did not). However I designed a Mark 2 bracket with the following upgrades. Extra buttressing on the M8 Bolt hole and a 5 degree offset to the bold hole to allow the spindle to sit at a 5 degree upward incline, causing the reel always to sit in the same place with no possibility of falling off.
New STL file is called Bracket_mk2

Print the three parts, Insert the M8 bolt in the captive hole on the bracket, Press fit the skateboard bearing into the spindle.
Fitting the lower filament guide will require a longer M3 nut than is on the printer

title: Camera Lens-Hood SMILE attachment - 58mm Canon T3i
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I came up with this idea while printing off a lens hood for my Canon Rebel T3i.
It's a decoration that can be attached using the same ring as the hood. You can put words, or design something with bobbles to make a child laugh or pay attention as you go for that perfect shot and get them to look right at the lens.
I've included the basic ring, as well as the "SMILE" version that I made in the attached files.
NOTE: This could mess with some people who use the "Auto" features on their camera. Such as Auto Focus, Light etc. The ring rotates as you zoom and focus, so it may not always be the right way up, and might block your auto focus beam. So it's not perfect, but good for a laugh.
Fits a 58mm Canon lens.
Enjoy!
This is open to anyone to modify and print, but is not for commercial use.

title: Silhouettes de Mon Oncle de Tati au 1/100°

description.text:
Silhouettes de Mon Oncle de Tati au 1/100° d'après l'affiche de la retrospective Tati.
Elles seront incorporées à la maquette au 1/100° de l'Eglise de Veneux-Les Sablons pour l'exposition/performance In Situ, "Art et Spirituel".
Renseignement sur https://www.facebook.com/events/1461855657430037/.
Multi-Champs Architectes & Associés SAS est heureux de vous communiquer sa présence à la manifestation culturel et artistique "Art et Spirituel" au travers d'une production In situ en impression 3D:
Acte artistique dans son processus de création, l’église est un catalyseur d’Art. Notre œuvre et démarche se propose d’explorer le rapport de l’homme à l’échelle et à la création architecturale au travers de l’impression 3D d’un modèle réduit au 1/100 ou 1/50° du bâtiment de notre église de Veneux-Les Sablons afin de nouer un dialogue entre le public et œuvre. Un Scanne 3D des protagonistes permettra alors de confronter ceux-ci à l’échelle de la conception en introduisant celui-ci dans la maquette. Art, Architecture et bâtiment ne feront alors qu’un pour la création d’une œuvre In Situ.
Silhouettes of Mon Oncle Tati 1/100 ° from the poster of Tati retrospective.
They will be incorporated into the model at 1 / 100th of the Church of Veneux-The Sablon for exhibition / performance In Situ, "Art and Spiritual."
Https://www.facebook.com/events/1461855657430037/ intelligence.
Multi-Champs SAS Architects & Associates is pleased to provide its presence in the cultural and artistic event "Art and Spiritual" through an in situ production 3D printing:
Artistic act in his creative process, the church is an Art catalyst. Our work approach and aims to explore the relationship of man to the scale and architectural design through 3D printing of a reduced 1/100 or 1/50 ° of the building of our church model Veneux-the Sablon to establish a dialogue between the public and work. 3D Scans protagonists will then compare them to the scale of the design by introducing it in the model. Art, Architecture and building will then become one to create a work Situ.

Infill: 100%
Number of Shells: 1
Layer Height: 0,10 mm
No Raft, no Supports
Times: 15mm

title: 30 x 80 Spool Holder for Replicator 1 or 2

description.text:
I was looking for a simple single part replacement for the proprietary and difficult to use MakerBot spool holders, and came across whpthomas's excellent design - except it was slightly too long for the space I have behind my MakerBot, and I don't need it for 5lb spools, just for 1Kg/1.5Kg spools from MakerBot and non MakerBot suppliers.
Not having Shark FX (~$1.7K!) I loaded the .stl into Blender ($0) and shortened the spool length to 8cm while keeping the rest of this excellent design as is, using the mesh editing tools.
I didn't do this to the flaps model - I did get some significant warping with ABS, but with Strong Hold Hairspray on a 110C Kapton tape bed, the print stayed attached to the end, and the warping doesn't effect its utility.
If you want to customise the model further, I recommend a logo or message on the 'back' of it, as this ends up being prime viewing real estate inside your maker bot.
whpthomas' design (and this deriviative) fitted fine on my Original Makerbot (1) (Dual).

Pull all the tricks you know to stick a print to your bed, this is a large print at it will lift - Hairspray, acetone / ABS paste, hot boxing, you are going to need it.
Or, you know, just use PLA on Painter Tape :-)

comments.text: I downloaded several of spool holders and after 3 or 4 I came across this one. It printed out beautifully and works great! Nicely done.

description.text: A 3D printable wing section.

Print a number of these and join them together end on end, and you've got one of the main parts of a 3D printable plane!   Scale it to whatever size you like.     Ive included three through-holes as an example of a way that you can "reinforce" your wing longitudinally, by inserting a section of ( for example ) carbon fibre tube down the centre hole, and optionally a smaller carbon fibre rod at the leading and/or trailing edge, as required ( this will depend on final size and scale , so it's up to you ).     I like to use 8mm carbon arrow-shaft for the main strut, as I have an archery shop nearby that sells me their left-overs for cheap! .   :-)

This is simply a low-poly version of a Wooly Mammoth I modeled a while ago.
Print with 7% infill with supports.

This early 20th century grave marker is another beautiful example of the prevailing notion of cemetery beautification through the monuments erected to the memory of its residents. Rustification, nature and subtle religious elements were blended together to create striking monuments like this one.

I set up my Nikon D200 on a tripod in Aperture Mode. As always, I shot my photos in the RAW format in case I'd need to make corrections later. I set my ISO to 100 and my lens to f/22 for maximum sharpness. The lens used was an old 50mm manual focus Nikon Series E.  
I then circled the grave marker making sure each time that my shot was in focus and as balanced as possible for good exposure. In this particular instance, I chose to do my photography when it was overcast so it would minimize the extremes of shadow or highlights.  
When I got home, I imported all my photos into Adobe Lightroom, rechecked them to be sure of their exposures and sharpness, made any necessary corrections and finally exported them as 16-bit TIFs. My next step was to mask each photo and export the resulting masks as PNGs.  
My final step was to import both the TIFs & PNG masks into Agisoft Photoscan. I set the preferences to create a model at the 'High' level of detail and accuracy, set my Macbook Pro to work and went to bed. By morning, after making a few extra tweaks, the model was ready to share.

title: Fully Parametric 90° Fan Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
a mount to attach a fan in an 90° angle to a surface.
fully parametric, in the scad-file you can define your fan-size, can adjust thickness, width, depth, height, material thickness and add sunks for countersunk screws.
supported fan types so far:
  • 40mm,
  • 60mm,
  • 80mm,
  • 92mm
  • 120mm
  • 135mm,
  • 140mm,
    if "your" fan size is missing just let me know, measure the outside frame edge and the center-to-center-hole-distance and i'll add it here.
    i know, not the best scad-style you might have seen so far, but it works as intended

the scad-file contains some variables you should adjust by yourself (all in mm):
  • fan_size //self-explaining
  • hole_dist //center-to-center-distance of the fans screw-holes
  • material_t // thickness of the "walls" of the mount
  • f_mnt_holes_dia // fan screw holes are usually 4.5mm in diameter (60mm, 80mm, 120mm, 140mm,...). 40mm fans have 3.5mm holes.
  • s_mnt_holes_dia // hole diameter of surface mount holes
  • extra_height // extra height above surface
  • extra_depth // extra depth of the surface flange
  • extra_width // extra width of the mount over the fan; improves stability of the fan mounting holes. set to '0' if needed
  • countersunk_surface // set to 1 if you want to use countersunk screws for the surface mount holes. will generate sunks on the screw holes
  • countersunk_fan // same as above, only for the fan mount holes

I was quite often in the situation, that a Print was incomplete because the friction of the spool to my self - printed Spool Holder was too high! So I thought a Spool holder with Bearings could do the trick...
I tried to construct something stable enough to hold heavy Spools but on the other Hand being light enough to roll well on the Bearings! I have also included the 123D Design Files, so you can adapt it to your needs! Have fun...

You need in addition an M6 Threaded Rod, two M6 Nuts, one M6 washer and 3 Ball Bearings 14*4mm
Glue one of the Washers into the Cap. the other one into the Base plate. Secure the Rod in the nut of the Base with Loctite Threadlock to prevent from turning during you fix the cap! Place the washer under the 2 Bearings on the Base to prvent the spool from rubbing on the base Plate! Glue the Holder with CA to the Base plate (Check proper position so it fits your printer!) Put everything together and have fun with a friction free Spool holder!
Used ABS Neon Green and Yellow at 230 deg. Nozzle Temp, MakerBot Standard setting with 15% infill and 2 shells

author: rdudek

description.text:
I like direct drive extruders since they are small with less parts however I find them not to be as reliable as geared extruders; with direct drive extruders I had problems with cheap filament since the tolerances are all over the place sometimes the direct drive lacks the power to push the filament through, not a problem with the geared extruder hence when I use good reliable expensive filament I'll go with the direct drive but with cheap filament I always feed it to my geared extruder machine.
Since all geared extruders seem to be large and I wanted something small I made this extruder a 1.75mm geared extruder with herringbone gears that have been reduced to 2/3 it's standard size to make it compact.
Latest version uses a bracket for mounting that allows to remove the extruder easily without tools.
The extruder is working fine however I am still working on it to make it better it might need some changes to please more people like the mounting bracket that might need other configurations for different machines, let me know.
You can always find the latest version and some other goodies in my site here is the link to the downloads area http://infill3d.com/20-downloads
Please let me know what you think, I want to end up using this extruder in a delta bot eventually.

Is a very straight forward extruder, here are the parts you are going to need...
1x Pneumatic fitting 1/8 to 4mm
2x 688ZZ Bearings (Extruder)
1x 608ZZ Bearing (Idler)
2x M3 Washers (Springs)
2x M3X45 Socket screw (Extruder to idler)
4x M3X8 Socket screw (Motor)
2x M3X16 Socket screw (Idler)
4x M3 Nuts (Idler, spring screws)
2x 1/4" x 1/2" x .035" (6.350 x 12.7 x .889mm) Untility comp springs (Extruder to idler)
6x M8 Washers (Hobbed bolt)
1x M8 Nyloc Nut (Hobbed Bolt)
1x Hobbed bolt (distances between the center of the groove and the base of the head should be 18.5mm +/-)
Be careful when you are treading the pneumatic fitting is easy to strip that area, I wanted to beef it up but space is limited in that area. It works fine just be careful not to apply too much force that could strip the plastic.
When mounting the motor notice the notch on the big gear is there to give access to the screws of the motor align the notch with the screws holes.
I debated about using a standard hobbed bolt however that would have made the extruder larger and I wanted it to be small hence I went with the current hobbed bolt (check picture) with that said if enough people asks for a regular bolt design I'll make some changes.
This version is in 1.75mm, I want to make a 3mm version however I been busy with other obligations, is there more people out there using 1.75mm or 3mm? I'll get around to make the 3mm version hopefully soon, let me know what you folks think.
Please send me some feedback since I want this extruder to go into the delta bot that I am working on.
Thank you everyone for your help.

title: Versatile, Cable Management System
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Firstly, this does look better in the real situation, the photos do not flatter it.
So, I wanted a cabling system for my Simple Printrbot.
See Instructions.
20/9/14 Uploaded 'Clip basic open 2 ends 5mm v9' and its spring part.
Hope its useful for those who prefered this option.
9/5/15 Have uploaded a hinged opener to help installation of these clips. The pictures, I hope, show how it works.

It has what I call an "outpost fixing". I have provided a single unit, a 4piece, and an 8piece.
These, can be mounted with a small countersunk screw, or the familiar cable tie. These hold the clips in place.
There is an "over clip", that can be used to hold a small bunch of wires if that is all you need.
But I use the "Basic clip front open", to attach the string of clips to the outpost fixing.
I have included a front mount, this is used on the Jon Lawrence, front mount that I have, the holes line up, and that was all I needed at the front. At the back I used the 8piece outpost fixing, and cable tied it to the simple frame that the mother board used to cling to. (I have it set back using my "Hinged Motherboard holder". http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:327793) You will need to scale the Z height, to make them taller, as I have only provided the basic 5mm versions, it's dead easy in Cura and Repetier.
For front and back mounting, I suggest 40mm high, then a "spring clip" to accomodate movement maybe 10mm high, then a couple of 20mm high basic clips, some more spring clips, some 10mm high basic clips, and more springs, and a mix of 5m clips and springs at the top, to allow movement.
I use good old curtain wire (the wire used to hold net curtains up), to hold the string of clips together, and this also holds the whole array, up and out of the way. It is strong enough if you needed it, to have the whole array horizontal. Make sure you make it long enough to go into the clips that sit in the outpost fixing, this keeps the whole thing steady.
The whole array allows twisting movement as well.
I have a variations of clips, and can't really decide which is best, front open or back open, or indeed the front and back open - held in the middle, I have provided an STL of this but it is not quiet there yet - it needs tweeking.
I have attempted to make an opener, to assist in holding the clip open while inserting wires, again, it could be improved I feel.
I can say that I am very happy the way this works, it holds all of the cables (motor, fan, fan, light, extruder, thermistor and sensor) from the front to the back in a tidy fashion. And of course, one can add to it making it longer or shorter if need be, and the number of clips one puts in the lenght is personal choice, totally closed or more exposed.
This could be adapted for other machines too.

This is a GoPro mount I designed that clip's into the front of your Ultimaker Printer!
Gives you a great adjustable shooting angle! ideal for making a Time lapse. *Can be mounted at every other side of the printer! Print it, mount it, enjoy it!

1) Print it with your 3d printer and use a support
2) Remove the support carefully
3) Mount it in the middle of your printer - starting from lower part - make sure you mount it centered with the hole for the skrew in the middle so it will fit tight.
be gentle with the wood!
*Can be mounted at every other side of the printer! 4) Clip your GoPro housing or use the GoPro naked mounting clip from here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25628
(Thanks to TechShopJim for the part!) If you want a better angle flexibility with the camera use the GoPro Straight Adaptor if you have one - or print one from here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:40291
(Thanks to mark133 for the part!) Enjoy!

title: Prototype style hand grip for Airsoft

description.text: This is an alternative hand grip for an airsoft mp5k. This style of hand grip was popularized in the video game "Call of Duty: Black Ops" where you can use one of the earlier versions of the Mp5k that featured this different front hand grip. Originally this is what the first Mp5k's hand guard looked like when H&K designed the weapon back in 1976. It was meant to protect users fingers from getting accidentally blown off, but was latter changed to the more widely recognized bulbous shaped hand grip. This replacement grip has been tested with a Tokyo Marui Mp5k. Wait till it arrives, spray paint it a matte, or textured black, and install on your Mp5k using the existing retaining pin!
Simply print it out and paint if you like, then use the existing pin that comes with the mp5k to install it!

For an "indoor apartment Mini-Golf Tournament" we are having, I built some Mini-Golf-Putters!
In combination with this golf ball: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6025
and some homemade obstacles it should be LOADS of fun!!!
As winter is slowly approaching.... (in middle Europe at least ;-) ) I thought I'd share it with you, in case you get snowed in and bored!

Print one MINIgolf_PUTTER.stl (I used the 0.3 layer resolution, 3 shells and 20% infill on a Makerbot Replicator 2) and it seems solid enough! Took exactly 1h to print.
Additionally you would need some wood or metal-rods. I used a 300mm long and 20mm in diameter round wood-rod as a handle (with a 10mm diameter hole drilled into one side and added a 650mm long and 10mm in diameter one with some wood glue.
To fix the 3D-printed part in place also add some glue or screw it from the outside!
I wrapped the handle with some black duct-tape (just for comfort)
The endresult should be an ~93cm long Standard Mini-Golf-Stick...
Have fun playing!!!
The 3D-printed putter holds a diameter of 10mm, but I added a blender file, in case you want to adjust it. In case there a standard imperial diameters you want to use, let me know and I can also upload an imperial file!

comments.text: My extended family has had epic indoor putt putt tourneys every few years since 1989.  Our original Nerf Putt Putt set was in a sad state and I was able to breathe new life (and consistency) into our equipment using this design.  Thank you for such a clean and usable putter!

Two layer print in PLA. Start with red (crimson) and as soon as the print changes from the base to the 'A' cut the filament and switch to a white PLA. After making a bunch of these I have found it easier to make at least four at a time. This will give you a better color separation when you switch colors. You guys with a single Bowden extruder may have to fuse filament pieces together.

This is Mount Massive near Leadville, CO.  A friend asked me to whip this up.  I used USGS NED elevation data, then into QGIS, then Meshlab, then Meshmixer.  This file is very large, with a lot of detail.  It is NOT to scale.  Can't remember which way is north on the darn thing either.  Enjoy.

I haven't printed this one yet, but I recommend printing vertically, in white, 2 shells and less than 10% infill. I doubt it needs support.
EDIT: Once I got this to the build plate, I reduced the height in the Z direction and printed it sitting flat on the bottom, NOT vertically. I was afraid there wasn't enough area on one edge to keep it stuck to the build plate. You might have more faith in your own abilities. Also I used gray filament and added the words.

As I mention in the Infill 3D Bowden geared extruder, I like direct drives I will go as far and say that aesthetically direct drives are ahead; less parts, smaller, less complicated but at the price of reliability. Once more I wanted a compact extruder that has the reliability of a Wade's extruder here is what I came up with.
I made this extruder to work with the SunBurn hotend and the Infill 3D i3R however it will work with any hotend that has a 16mm groove mount, I wanted the extruder to be small and give me back some Z axis printing volume; from the bottom of the X-Carriage to the tip of the SunBurn hotend (this measurement will be different with other hotends) there is only 10mm+/- I could have gone lower but I wanted to play it safe.
Also it uses the same small 2/3 herringbone gears as my Bowden extruder making it very compact, check the pictures one of them has a quarter dollar coin for refrerence, I have been using it for the past few months and is been performing well.
Latest version and X-Carriage is at http://infill3d.com/20-downloads along with other parts that might interest Prusa i3 users.
If you find any errors or have any ideas for improvement let me know.

I have a couple of X-carriages for the i3 that were made for this extruder, they have a corner notch to allow for a standard gear size extruder in the event that you wish to change extruders check the download are of my site.
Some parts are small hence I highly recommend to print as many as possible in one go so there no issues with heat,
You are going to need...
3x 688ZZ Bearings (Extruder, Idler)
10x M3 Nuts (Extruder, idler, clamp, carrier)
2x M3 Washers (Springs)
2x M3X45 Socket screw (Extruder to idler)
4x M3X8 Socket screw (Motor)
2x M3X16 Socket screw (Idler)
2x M3X18 Socket screw (Clamp)
4x M3X25 Socket screw (Carrier)
2x 1/4" x 1/2" x .035" (6.350 x 12.7 x .889mm) Utility comp springs (Extruder to idler)
4x M8 Washers (Hobbed bolt)
2x M8 Nuts (Hobbed Bolt)
1x Hobbed bolt (distances between the center of the groove and the base of the head should be 25mm +/-)
